    <us-gaap:DebtDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-06-
30">&lt;div style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;table 
id="zcaee08a489c7401baac342ce9159ff6e" class="DSPFListTable" cellspacing="0" 
cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 36pt; font: bold 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, serif; vertical-align: top"&gt;3.&lt;/td&gt;&#13;&lt;td 
style="text-align: justify; width: auto; font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times,
serif; vertical-align: top"&gt;Credit Agreement &amp;#8211; Beta Project 
Financing&lt;/td&gt;&#13;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#1
3;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: 
justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;In November 2012, the Fund
entered into a credit agreement (the &amp;#8220;Credit Agreement&amp;#8221;) 
with Rahr Energy Investments LLC, as Administrative Agent and Lender (and any 
other banks or financial institutions that may in the future become a party 
thereto, collectively &amp;#8220;Lenders&amp;#8221;) that provides for an 
aggregate loan commitment to the Fund of approximately $24.1 million 
(&amp;#8220;Loan&amp;#8221;), to provide capital toward the funding of the 
Fund&amp;#8217;s share of development costs on the Beta Project. Except in cases
of fraud and breach of certain representations, the Loan is non-recourse to the 
Fund&amp;#8217;s other assets and secured solely by the Fund&amp;#8217;s 
interests in the Beta Project. Certain other funds managed by Ridgewood 
(&amp;#8220;Ridgewood Funds&amp;#8221;, and when used with the Fund the
&amp;#8220;Ridgewood Participating Funds&amp;#8221;) have also executed the 
Credit Agreement. Pursuant to the Credit Agreement, each Ridgewood Participating
Fund has a separate loan commitment from the Lenders and amounts borrowed are 
not joint and several obligations. Each of the Ridgewood Participating 
Funds&amp;#8217; borrowings is secured solely by its separate interest in the 
Beta Project. Therefore, the Fund is liable for the repayment of its Loan and is
not liable to the Lenders to repay any loan made to any other Ridgewood Funds. 
The Manager serves as the manager for each of the Ridgewood Participating 
Funds.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The Fund anticipates it will borrow 
approximately $24.1 million over the development period of the Beta Project. The
Loan bears interest at 8% compounded annually and accrues only on Loan proceeds 
as they are drawn. Principal and interest will not be payable until such time 
that initial production has commenced for the Beta Project, which commenced 
production in third quarter 2016.&amp;#160; At that time, if certain revenue 
production levels are met, principal and interest will be repaid at a monthly 
rate of 1.25% of the Fund&amp;#8217;s total principal outstanding at the date 
the Beta Project commences production for the first seven months of production, 
and a monthly rate of 4.5% of the Fund&amp;#8217;s total principal outstanding 
at the date the Beta Project commences production thereafter until the Loan is 
repaid in full, in no event later than December 31, 2020.&amp;#160; The Loan may
be prepaid by the Fund without premium or 
penalty.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;As of June 30, 2016 and December 31, 2015, the
Fund had borrowings of $22.8 million under the Credit Agreement. During the 
first quarter of 2016, the Fund adopted the accounting guidance issued in April 
2015 related to the presentation of debt issuance costs on the balance sheet as 
a direct reduction from the carrying amount of the debt liability, rather than 
as an asset. As a result, the unamortized debt discounts and deferred financing 
costs of $0.5 million as of June 30, 2016 and $0.7 million as of December 31, 
2015 are presented as a reduction of &amp;#8220;Long-term borrowings&amp;#8221; 
on the balance sheets.&amp;#160; As of June 30, 2016 and December 31, 2015, 
interest costs of $2.2 million and $1.3 million, respectively, were capitalized 
and included on the balance sheet within &amp;#8220;Oil and gas 
properties&amp;#8221;.&amp;#160; Such amounts are accrued on the balance sheet 
within &amp;#8220;Accrued expenses&amp;#8221; as of June 30, 2016 and 
&amp;#8220;Accrued expenses&amp;#8221; and &amp;#8220;Other 
liabilities&amp;#8221; as of December 31, 
2015.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;As additional consideration to the Lenders, 
the Fund has agreed to convey an overriding royalty interest 
(&amp;#8220;ORRI&amp;#8221;) in its working interest in the Beta Project to the 
Lenders.&amp;#160; The Credit Agreement contains customary covenants, for which 
the Fund believes it was in compliance as of June 30, 2016 and December 31, 
2015.&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:DebtDisclosureTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="D2016-
01-01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: left"&gt;&lt;table 
id="zd86ef47c2b1d4db0a738fb91a4f1ed4b" class="DSPFListTable" cellspacing="0" 
cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 36pt; font: bold 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, serif; vertical-align: top"&gt;4.&lt;/td&gt;&#13;&lt;td 
style="text-align: left; width: auto; font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif; vertical-align: top"&gt;Commitments and 
Contingencies&lt;/td&gt;&#13;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13
;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-
align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Capital
Commitments&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The Fund has entered into multiple agreements 
for the acquisition, drilling and development of its oil and gas properties. The
estimated capital expenditures associated with these agreements vary depending 
on the stage of development on a property-by-property basis.&amp;#160; As of
June 30, 2016, the Fund had one property, the Beta Project, for which additional
development costs must be incurred in order to commence production.&amp;#160; 
The Fund currently expects to spend an additional $11.3 million (which includes 
asset retirement obligations) related to the development of the Beta Project, 
which the Fund anticipates will include the development of four wells with 
related platform and pipeline infrastructure.&amp;#160; During third quarter 
2016, one well in the Beta Project commenced 
production.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;As of June 30, 2016, the Fund&amp;#8217;s 
estimated capital commitments related to its oil and gas properties were $18.5 
million (which include asset retirement obligations for the Fund&amp;#8217;s 
projects of $5.9 million and projected interest costs of $0.2 million for the 
Beta Project), of which $7.2 million is expected to be spent during the next 
twelve months. These expected capital commitments exceed available working 
capital and salvage fund by $19.1 million as of June 30, 2016.&amp;#160; The 
Fund has entered into the Credit Agreement to provide capital for funding of the
Beta Project.&amp;#160; See Note 3. &amp;#8220;Credit Agreement &amp;#8211; Beta
Project Financing&amp;#8221; for additional 
information.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt
Times New Roman, Times, 
serif"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: 
justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Based upon its current 
cash position, its current reserve estimates and its current development plan of
the Beta Project, the Fund expects cash flow from operations and borrowings to 
be sufficient to cover its commitments, as well as ongoing operations. Reserve 
estimates are projections based on engineering data that cannot be measured with
precision, require substantial judgment, and are subject to frequent 
revision.&amp;#160; However, if cash flow from operations is not sufficient to 
meet the Fund&amp;#8217;s capital commitments, the Manager will take action, 
which may include adjusting its management fee temporarily or acquiring short-
term debt to accommodate the Fund&amp;#8217;s short-term capital 
commitments.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: italic
bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Environmental 
Considerations&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The exploration for and development of 
oil and natural gas involves the extraction, production and transportation of 
materials which, under certain conditions, can be hazardous or cause 
environmental pollution problems.&amp;#160; The Manager and operators of the 
Fund&amp;#8217;s properties are continually taking action they believe 
appropriate to satisfy applicable federal, state and local environmental 
regulations and do not currently anticipate that compliance with federal, state 
and local environmental regulations will have a material adverse effect upon 
capital expenditures, results of operations or the competitive position of the 
Fund in the oil and gas industry.&amp;#160; However, due to the significant 
public and governmental interest in environmental matters related to those 
activities, the Manager cannot predict the effects of possible future 
legislation, rule changes, or governmental or private claims.&amp;#160; As of 
June 30, 2016 and December 31, 2015, there were no known environmental 
contingencies that required adjustment to, or disclosure in, the 
Fund&amp;#8217;s financial statements.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;During the past several years, the United 
States Congress, as well as certain regulatory agencies with jurisdiction over 
the Fund&amp;#8217;s business, have considered or proposed legislation or 
regulation relating to the upstream oil and gas industry both onshore and 
offshore.&amp;#160; If any such proposals were to be enacted or adopted they 
could potentially materially impact the Fund&amp;#8217;s operations.&amp;#160; 
It is not possible at this time to predict whether such legislation or 
regulation, if proposed, will be adopted as initially written, if at all, or how
legislation or new regulation that may be adopted would impact the 
Fund&amp;#8217;s business. Any such future laws and regulations could result in 
increased compliance costs or additional operating restrictions, which could
have a material adverse effect on the Fund&amp;#8217;s operating results and 
cash flows.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: italic
bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Insurance 
Coverage&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The Fund is subject to all risks inherent in 
the exploration for and development of oil and natural gas. Insurance coverage 
as is customary for entities engaged in similar operations is maintained, but 
losses may occur from uninsurable risks or amounts in excess of existing 
insurance coverage.&amp;#160; The occurrence of an event that is not insured or 
not fully insured could have a material adverse impact upon earnings and 
financial position.&amp;#160; Moreover, insurance is obtained as a package 
covering all of the funds managed by the Manager.&amp;#160; Claims made by other
funds managed by the Manager can reduce or eliminate insurance for the 
Fund.&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:BasisOfAccountingPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-
01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: 
justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Basis of 
Presentation&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;These unaudited interim condensed financial 
statements have been prepared by the Fund&amp;#8217;s management in accordance 
with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America 
(&amp;#8220;GAAP&amp;#8221;) and in the opinion of management, contain all 
adjustments (consisting of only normal recurring adjustments) necessary to 
present fairly the Fund&amp;#8217;s financial position, results of operations 
and cash flows for the periods presented.&amp;#160; Certain information and note
disclosures normally included in annual financial statements prepared in 
accordance with GAAP have been omitted in these unaudited interim condensed 
financial statements.&amp;#160; The results of operations, financial position, 
and cash flows for the periods presented herein are not necessarily indicative 
of future financial results.&amp;#160; These unaudited interim condensed 
financial statements should be read in conjunction with the Fund&amp;#8217;s 
December 31, 2015 financial statements and notes thereto included in the 
Fund&amp;#8217;s Annual Report on Form 10-K filed with the Securities and 
Exchange Commission (&amp;#8220;SEC&amp;#8221;).&amp;#160; The year-end 
condensed balance sheet data was derived from audited financial statements for 
the year ended December 31, 2015, but does not include all disclosures required 
by GAAP.&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:BasisOfAccountingPolicyPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:UseOfEstimates contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div 
style="text-align: left; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif"&gt;Use of Estimates&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: 
justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The preparation of 
financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires management to make 
estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and 
liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities as of the date 
of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expense 
during the reporting period. On an ongoing basis, the Manager reviews its 
estimates, including those related to the fair value of financial instruments, 
net property balances, determination of proved reserves, impairment of long-
lived assets and asset retirement obligations. Actual results may differ from 
those estimates.&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:UseOfEstimates>
    <us-gaap:FairValueMeasurementPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-
01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: 
justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Fair Value 
Measurements&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The fair value measurement guidance provides a
hierarchy that prioritizes and defines the types of inputs used to measure fair 
value. The fair value hierarchy gives the highest priority to Level 1 inputs, 
which consists of unadjusted quoted prices for identical instruments in active 
markets. Level 2 inputs consist of quoted prices for similar 
instruments.&amp;#160; Level 3 inputs are unobservable inputs and include 
situations where there is little, if any, market activity for the instrument; 
hence, these inputs have the lowest priority.&lt;/div&gt;</us-
gaap:FairValueMeasurementPolicyPolicyTextBlock>
<us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-
01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Cash and Cash 
Equivalents&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;All highly liquid investments with maturities,
when purchased, of three months or less, are considered cash equivalents. These 
balances, as well as cash on hand, are included in &amp;#8220;Cash and cash 
equivalents&amp;#8221; on the balance sheet. As of June 30, 2016, the Fund had 
no cash equivalents. At times, deposits may be in excess of federally insured 
limits, which are $250 thousand per insured financial institution.&amp;#160; As 
of June 30, 2016, the Fund&amp;#8217;s bank balances were maintained in 
uninsured bank accounts at Wells Fargo Bank, N.A.&lt;/div&gt;</us-
gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsPolicyTextBlock>
    <cik1315061:SalvageFundPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-06-
30">&lt;div style="text-align: left; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, serif"&gt;Salvage Fund&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: 
justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The Fund deposits in a 
separate interest-bearing account, or salvage fund, money to provide for the 
dismantling and removal of production platforms and facilities and plugging and 
abandoning its wells at the end of their useful lives in accordance with 
applicable federal and state laws and regulations. Interest earned on the 
account will become part of the salvage fund. There are no restrictions on 
withdrawals from the salvage 
fund.&lt;/div&gt;</cik1315061:SalvageFundPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:DebtPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div 
style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif"&gt;Debt Discounts and Deferred Financing 
Costs&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Debt discounts and deferred financing costs include 
lender fees and other costs of acquiring debt (see Note 3. &amp;#8220;Credit 
Agreement &amp;#8211; Beta Project Financing&amp;#8221;) such as the conveyance 
of override royalty interests related to the Beta Project.&amp;#160; These costs
are deferred and amortized over the term of the debt period or until the 
redemption of the debt. During the first quarter of 2016, the Fund adopted the 
accounting guidance issued in April 2015 related to the presentation of debt 
issuance costs on the balance sheet as a direct reduction from the carrying 
amount of the debt liability, rather than as an asset. As a result, the 
unamortized debt discounts and deferred financing costs of $0.5 million as of 
June 30, 2016 and $0.7 million as of December 31, 2015 are presented 
as&amp;#160;a reduction of &amp;#8220;Long-term borrowings&amp;#8221; on the 
balance sheets. Amortization expense was $0.1 million during each of the three 
months ended June 30, 2016 and 2015.&amp;#160; Amortization expense was $0.2 
million during each of the six months ended June 30, 2016 and 2015.&amp;#160; 
During the period of asset construction, amortization expense, as a component of
interest, is capitalized and included on the balance sheet within &amp;#8220;Oil
and gas properties&amp;#8221;.&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:DebtPolicyTextBlock>
    <cik1315061:InvestmentInEquipmentAndFacilitiesPolicyTextBlock 
contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: left; font: 
italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Investment in Delta 
House&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div 
style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The 
Fund has investments in Delta House Oil and Gas Lateral, LLC and Delta House 
FPS, LLC (collectively &amp;#8220;Delta House&amp;#8221;), legal entities that 
own interests in a deepwater floating production system operated by LLOG 
Exploration Company.&amp;#160; The Fund accounts for its investment in Delta 
House using the cost method of accounting for investments as it does not have 
the ability to exercise significant influence over such investment.&amp;#160; 
Under the cost method, the Fund recognizes an investment in the equity of an 
investee at cost.&amp;#160;&amp;#160; The Fund recognizes&amp;#160;as income 
dividends received that are distributed from net accumulated earnings of the 
investee since the date of acquisition by the Fund.&amp;#160; Dividends received
in excess of earnings subsequent to the date of investment are considered a 
return of investment and are recorded as reductions of cost of the investment. 
The Fund reviews its cost method investment for impairment at each reporting
period and when an event or change in circumstances has occurred that may have 
significant adverse effect on the fair value of the investment.&amp;#160; As of 
June 30, 2016, there are no such events or changes in circumstances that 
indicate that the Fund&amp;#8217;s investment in Delta House is 
impaired.&lt;/div&gt;</cik1315061:InvestmentInEquipmentAndFacilitiesPolicyTextBl
ock>
    <us-gaap:FullCostOrSuccessfulEffortsPolicy contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-
06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Oil and Gas Properties&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div 
style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The 
Fund invests in oil and gas properties, which are operated by unaffiliated 
entities that are responsible for drilling, administering and producing 
activities pursuant to the terms of the applicable operating agreements with 
working interest owners. The Fund&amp;#8217;s portion of exploration, drilling, 
operating and capital equipment expenditures is billed by 
operators.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;d
iv style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif"&gt;Exploration, development and acquisition costs are accounted for using
the successful efforts method. Costs of acquiring unproved and proved oil and 
natural gas leasehold acreage, including lease bonuses, brokers&amp;#8217; fees 
and other related costs are capitalized. Costs of drilling and equipping 
productive wells and related production facilities are capitalized.&amp;#160; 
The costs of exploratory wells are capitalized pending determination of whether 
proved reserves have been found.&amp;#160; If proved commercial reserves are not
found, exploratory well costs are expensed as dry-hole costs.&amp;#160; At 
times, the Fund receives adjustments to certain wells from their respective 
operators upon review and audit of the wells&amp;#8217; costs.&amp;#160; 
Interest costs related to the Credit Agreement (see Note 3. &amp;#8220;Credit 
Agreement &amp;#8211; Beta Project Financing&amp;#8221;) are capitalized during 
the period of asset construction. Annual lease rentals and exploration expenses 
are expensed as incurred.&amp;#160; All costs related to production activity, 
transportation expense and workover efforts are expensed as 
incurred.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Once a well has been determined to be fully 
depleted or upon the sale, retirement or abandonment of a property, the cost and
related accumulated depletion and amortization, if any, is eliminated from the 
property accounts, and the resultant gain or loss is 
recognized.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;As of June 30, 2016 and December 31, 2015, 
amounts recorded in due to operators totaling $1.0 million and $0.5 million, 
respectively, related to capital expenditures for oil and gas 
properties.&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:FullCostOrSuccessfulEffortsPolicy>
    
<cik1315061:AdvancesToOperatorsForWorkingInterestsAndExpendituresPolicyTextBlock
contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font:
italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Advances to Operators for 
Working Interests and Expenditures&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-
align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The Fund may be 
required to advance its share of the estimated succeeding month&amp;#8217;s 
expenditures to the operator for its oil and gas properties. As the costs are 
incurred, the advances are reclassified to proved 
properties.&lt;/div&gt;</cik1315061:AdvancesToOperatorsForWorkingInterestsAndExp
endituresPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:AssetRetirementObligationsPolicy contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-
06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Asset Retirement 
Obligations&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;For oil and gas properties, there are 
obligations to perform removal and remediation activities when the properties 
are retired. Upon the determination of a property to be either proved or dry, a 
retirement obligation is incurred. The Fund recognizes the fair value of a 
liability for an asset retirement obligation in the period incurred.&amp;#160;
Plug and abandonment costs associated with unsuccessful projects are expensed as
dry-hole costs.&amp;#160; As indicated above, the Fund maintains a salvage fund 
to provide for the funding of asset retirement obligations.&lt;/div&gt;</us-
gaap:AssetRetirementObligationsPolicy>
    <cik1315061:SyndicationCostsPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-
06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Syndication Costs&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div 
style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif"&gt;Syndication costs are direct costs incurred by the Fund in connection 
with the offering of the Fund&amp;#8217;s shares, including professional fees, 
selling expenses and administrative costs payable to the Manager, an affiliate 
of the Manager and unaffiliated broker-dealers, which are reflected on the 
Fund&amp;#8217;s balance sheet as a reduction of shareholders&amp;#8217; 
capital.&lt;/div&gt;</cik1315061:SyndicationCostsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:RevenueRecognitionPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-
06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Revenue Recognition and 
Imbalances&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Oil and gas revenues are recognized when oil 
and gas is sold to a purchaser at a fixed or determinable price, when delivery 
has occurred and title has transferred, and collectability of the revenue is 
reasonably assured.&amp;#160; The Fund uses the sales method of accounting for 
gas production imbalances.&amp;#160; The volumes of gas sold may differ from the
volumes to which the Fund is entitled based on its interests in the 
properties.&amp;#160; These differences create imbalances that are recognized as
a liability only when the properties&amp;#8217; estimated remaining reserves net
to the Fund will not be sufficient to enable the underproduced owner to recoup 
its entitled share through production.&amp;#160; The Fund&amp;#8217;s recorded 
liability, if any, would be reflected in other liabilities.&amp;#160; No 
receivables are recorded for those wells where the Fund has taken less than its 
share of production.&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:RevenueRecognitionPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:ImpairmentOrDisposalOfLongLivedAssetsPolicyTextBlock 
contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font:
italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Impairment of Long-Lived 
Assets&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;The Fund reviews the carrying value of its oil and 
gas properties annually and when management determines that events and 
circumstances indicate that the recorded carrying value of properties may not be
recoverable.&amp;#160; Impairments are determined by comparing estimated future 
net undiscounted cash flows to the carrying value at the time of the 
review.&amp;#160; If the carrying value exceeds the estimated future net 
undiscounted cash flows, the carrying value of the asset is written down to fair
value, which is determined using estimated future net discounted cash flows from
the asset.&amp;#160; The fair value determinations require considerable judgment
and are sensitive to change.&amp;#160; Different pricing assumptions, reserve 
estimates or discount rates could result in a different calculated 
impairment.&amp;#160; Given the volatility of oil and natural gas prices, it is 
reasonably possible that the Fund&amp;#8217;s estimate of discounted future net 
cash flows from proved oil and natural gas reserves could change in the near 
term.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Significant declines in oil and natural gas 
prices since fourth quarter 2014 have impacted the fair value of the 
Fund&amp;#8217;s oil and gas properties. During the six months ended June 30, 
2016, the Fund recorded impairments of oil and gas properties of $13 thousand, 
which represented the carrying value of Eugene Island 346/347.&amp;#160; The 
impairment was primarily attributable to declines in future oil and gas 
prices.&amp;#160; There were no impairments of oil and gas properties during the
three months ended June 30, 2016 and during the three and six months ended June 
30, 2015.&amp;#160; If oil and natural gas prices continue to decline, even if 
only for a short period of time, it is possible that additional impairments of 
oil and gas properties will occur.&lt;/div&gt;</us-
gaap:ImpairmentOrDisposalOfLongLivedAssetsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:PropertyPlantAndEquipmentPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-
01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: 
justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Depletion and 
Amortization&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Depletion and amortization of the cost of 
proved oil and gas properties are calculated using the units-of-production 
method.&amp;#160; Proved developed reserves are used as the base for depleting 
capitalized costs associated with successful exploratory well costs, development
costs and related facilities. The sum of proved developed and proved undeveloped
reserves is used as the base for depleting or amortizing leasehold acquisition 
costs.&amp;#160; During the three and six months ended June 30, 2015, the Fund 
recorded $0.2 million of depletion expense related to adjustments to asset 
retirement obligations for fully depleted properties.&lt;/div&gt;</us-
gaap:PropertyPlantAndEquipmentPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-06-
30">&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 
italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Income 
Taxes&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;No provision is made for income taxes in the 
financial statements.&amp;#160; The Fund is a limited liability company, and as 
such, the Fund&amp;#8217;s income or loss is passed through and included in the 
tax returns of the Fund&amp;#8217;s shareholders.&amp;#160; The Fund files U.S. 
Federal and State tax returns and the 2013 through 2015 tax returns remain open 
for examination by tax authorities.&lt;/div&gt;</us-
gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock>
    <cik1315061:IncomeAndExpenseAllocationPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-
01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Income and Expense 
Allocation&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Profits and losses are allocated to 
shareholders and the Manager in accordance with the LLC 
Agreement.&lt;/div&gt;</cik1315061:IncomeAndExpenseAllocationPolicyTextBlock>
    <cik1315061:DistributionsPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-01-01_To_2016-06-
30">&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 
italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif"&gt;Distributions&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify;
font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Distributions to shareholders are 
allocated in proportion to the number of shares held.&amp;#160; The Manager 
determines whether available cash from operations, as defined in the LLC 
Agreement, will be distributed. Such distributions are allocated 85% to the 
shareholders and 15% to the Manager, as required by the LLC 
Agreement.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Available cash from dispositions, as defined 
in the LLC Agreement, will be paid 99% to shareholders and 1% to the Manager 
until the shareholders have received total distributions equal to their capital 
contributions.&amp;#160; After shareholders have received distributions equal to
their capital contributions, 85% of available cash from dispositions will be 
distributed to shareholders and 15% to the 
Manager.&lt;/div&gt;</cik1315061:DistributionsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:NewAccountingPronouncementsPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="D2016-
01-01_To_2016-06-30">&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;Recent Accounting 
Pronouncements&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;In January 2016, the Financial Accounting
Standards Board (&amp;#8220;FASB&amp;#8221;) issued accounting guidance that 
requires, among other things, companies to measure investments in other 
entities, except those accounted for under the equity method, at fair value and 
recognize any changes in fair value in net income unless an election is made to 
record the investment at cost, less impairment and plus or minus subsequent 
adjustments for observable price changes with change in basis reported in 
current earnings. This pronouncement is effective for fiscal years beginning 
after December 15, 2017 and interim periods within those fiscal years, with 
early adoption not permitted. The Fund is currently evaluating the impact of 
this guidance on its financial
statements.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;In April 2015, the FASB issued accounting 
guidance related to the presentation of debt issuance costs on the balance sheet
as a direct reduction from the carrying amount of the debt liability, consistent
with debt discounts, rather than as an asset.&amp;#160; Amortization of debt 
issuance costs will continue to be reported as interest expense.&amp;#160; In 
August 2015, the FASB issued accounting guidance related to the presentation and
subsequent measurement of debt issuance costs associated with line-of-credit 
arrangements which clarifies that companies may continue to present unamortized 
debt issuance costs associated with line of credit arrangements as an 
asset.&amp;#160; These pronouncements are effective for fiscal years, and 
interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2015, with 
early adoption permitted.&amp;#160; The Fund adopted the accounting guidance in 
first quarter 2016, resulting in a one-time reclassification of $0.7 million of 
unamortized debt discounts and deferred financing costs from "Other assets" to 
"Long-term borrowings" on the balance sheet as of December 31, 2015. Long-term 
borrowings are presented net of $0.5 million of unamortized debt discounts and 
deferred financing costs as of June 30, 2016. The adoption of these 
pronouncements did not impact the Fund&amp;#8217;s results of operations or cash
flows.&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br 
/&gt;&#13;&lt;/div&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, serif"&gt;In 2014, the FASB issued accounting guidance 
on revenue recognition, which provides for a single five-step model to be 
applied to all revenue contracts with customers. In 2015, the FASB issued a 
deferral of the effective date of the guidance to 2018, with early adoption 
permitted in 2017. In May 2016, the FASB issued final amendments which provided 
narrow scope improvements and practical expedients related to the implementation
of the guidance. The Fund is currently evaluating the impact of this guidance on
its financial statements.&lt;/div&gt;</us-
gaap:NewAccountingPronouncementsPolicyPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:Depletion contextRef="D2015-01-01_To_2015-06-30" unitRef="USD" 
decimals="-3">200000</us-gaap:Depletion>
    <us-gaap:Depletion contextRef="From2015-04-01to2015-06-30" unitRef="USD"

    <element id="cik1315061_SalvageFundNoncurrent" name="SalvageFundNoncurrent" 
nillable="true" xbrli:periodType="instant" xbrli:balance="debit" 
type="xbrli:monetaryItemType" substitutionGroup="xbrli:item" />
    <element id="cik1315061_InvestmentInEquipmentAndFacilities" 
name="InvestmentInEquipmentAndFacilities" nillable="true" 
xbrli:periodType="instant" xbrli:balance="debit" type="xbrli:monetaryItemType" 
substitutionGroup="xbrli:item" />
    <element id="cik1315061_ManagerDistributions" name="ManagerDistributions" 
nillable="true" xbrli:periodType="instant" xbrli:balance="debit"

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" 
style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_AccountsPayableCurrent">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Carrying value as of the balance sheet date of liabilities
incurred (and for which invoices have typically been received) and payable to 
vendors for goods and services received that are used in an entity's business. 
Used to reflect the current portion of the liabilities (due within one year or 
within the normal operating cycle if longer).</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ 
References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: 
http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name 
Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section 
S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02.19(a))<br> -URI

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" 
style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_AccountsReceivableNetCurrent">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Amount due from customers or clients, within one year of 
the balance sheet date (or the normal operating cycle, whichever is longer), for
goods or services (including trade receivables) that have been delivered or sold
in the normal course of business, reduced to the estimated net realizable fair 
value by an allowance established by the entity of the amount it deems uncertain
of collection.</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ 
References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: 
http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name 
Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section 
S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02(3))<br> -URI 
http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-
122682<br><br>Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef<br> 
-Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br> 
-SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-
02(4))<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-

</tr>

<td><strong> Period Type:</strong></td>
<td>instant</td>
</tr>
</table></div>
</div></td></tr>
</table>
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" 
style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_AccruedLiabilitiesCurrent">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Carrying value as of the balance sheet date of obligations
incurred and payable, pertaining to costs that are statutory in nature, are 
incurred on contractual obligations, or accumulate over time and for which 
invoices have not yet been received or will not be rendered. Examples include 
taxes, interest, rent and utilities. Used to reflect the current portion of the 
liabilities (due within one year or within the normal operating cycle if 
longer).</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ 
References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: 
http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name

S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02.20)<br> -URI 
http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-
122682<br></p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" 
style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_AssetRetirementObligationsNoncurrent">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Noncurrent portion of the carrying amount of a liability 
for an asset retirement obligation. An asset retirement obligation is a legal 
obligation associated with the disposal or retirement of a tangible long-lived 
asset that results from the acquisition, construction or development, or the 
normal operations of a long-lived asset, except for certain obligations of 
lessees.</p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" 
style="display: none;" id="defref_us-
gaap_CashAndCashEquivalentsAtCarryingValue">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Amount of currency on hand as well as demand deposits with
banks or financial institutions. Includes other kinds of accounts that have the 
general characteristics of demand deposits. Also includes short-term, highly 
liquid investments that are both readily convertible to known amounts of cash 
and so near their maturity that they present insignificant risk of changes in 
value because of changes in interest rates. Excludes cash and cash equivalents 
within disposal group and discontinued operation.</p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" 
style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_CommitmentsAndContingencies">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Represents the caption on the face of the balance sheet to
indicate that the entity has entered into (1) purchase or supply arrangements 
that will require expending a portion of its resources to meet the terms 
thereof, and (2) is exposed to potential losses or, less frequently, gains, 
arising from (a) possible claims against a company's resources due to future 
performance under contract terms, and (b) possible losses or likely gains from 
uncertainties that will ultimately be resolved when one or more future events 
that are deemed likely to occur do occur or fail to occur.</p></div>

<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Amount, after unamortized (discount) premium and debt 
issuance costs, of long-term debt, classified as current. Includes, but not 
limited to, notes payable, bonds payable, debentures, mortgage loans and 
commercial paper. Excludes capital lease obligations.</p></div>

<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Amount after unamortized (discount) premium and debt 
issuance costs of long-term debt classified as noncurrent and excluding amounts 
to be repaid within one year or the normal operating cycle, if longer. Includes,
but not limited to, notes payable, bonds payable, debentures, mortgage loans and
commercial paper. Excludes capital lease obligations.</p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" 
style="display: none;" id="defref_us-gaap_StockholdersEquity">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Total of all stockholders' equity (deficit) items, net of 
receivables from officers, directors, owners, and affiliates of the entity which
are attributable to the parent. The amount of the economic entity's 
stockholders' equity attributable to the parent excludes the amount of 
stockholders' equity which is allocable to that ownership interest in subsidiary
equity which is not attributable to the parent (noncontrolling interest, 
minority interest). This excludes temporary equity and is sometimes called 
permanent equity.</p></div>
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ 
References</a><div style="display: none;"><p>Reference 1: 
http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef<br> -Publisher FASB<br> -Name 
Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br> -SubTopic 10<br> -Section 
S99<br> -Paragraph 1<br> -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02(30))<br> -URI 
http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-
122682<br><br>Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef<br> 
-Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 310<br> 
-SubTopic 10<br> -Section S99<br> -Paragraph 2<br> -Subparagraph (SAB Topic 
4.E)<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=27010918&amp;loc=d3e74512-
122707<br><br>Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef<br> 
-Publisher FASB<br> -Name Accounting Standards Codification<br> -Topic 210<br>

02(31))<br> -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6877327&amp;loc=d3e13212-

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" 
style="display: none;" id="defref_us-
gaap_AssetRetirementObligationAccretionExpense">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Amount of accretion expense recognized during the period 
that is associated with an asset retirement obligation. Accretion expense
measures and incorporates changes due to the passage of time into the carrying 
amount of the liability.</p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" 
style="display: none;" id="defref_us-
gaap_CashAndCashEquivalentsAtCarryingValue">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Amount of currency on hand as well as demand deposits with
banks or financial institutions. Includes other kinds of accounts that have the 
general characteristics of demand deposits. Also includes short-term, highly 
liquid investments that are both readily convertible to known amounts of cash 
and so near their maturity that they present insignificant risk of changes in 
value because of changes in interest rates. Excludes cash and cash equivalents 
within disposal group and discontinued operation.</p></div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData"

gaap_CashAndCashEquivalentsPeriodIncreaseDecrease">
<tr><td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td></tr>
<tr><td><div class="body" style="padding: 2px;">
<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div><p>Amount of increase (decrease) in cash and cash 
equivalents. Cash and cash equivalents are the amount of currency on hand as 
well as demand deposits with banks or financial institutions. Includes other 
kinds of accounts that have the general characteristics of demand deposits. Also
includes short-term, highly liquid investments that are both readily convertible
to known amounts of cash and so near their maturity that they present 
insignificant risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates. 
Includes effect from exchange rate changes.</p></div>

Definition</a><div><p>Amount of cash inflow (outflow) of financing activities, 
excluding discontinued operations. Financing activity cash flows include 
obtaining resources from owners and providing them with a return on, and a 
return of, their investment; borrowing money and repaying amounts borrowed, or 
settling the obligation; and obtaining and paying for other resources obtained 
from creditors on long-term credit.</p></div>

<td>duration</td>
</tr>
</table></div>
</div></td></tr>
</table>

excluding discontinued operations. Investing activity cash flows include making 
and collecting loans and acquiring and disposing of debt or equity instruments 
and property, plant, and equipment and other productive assets.</p></div>

<body>
<span style="display: none;">v3.5.0.2</span><table class="report" border="0" 
cellspacing="2" id="idp6789021360">
<tr>
<th class="tl" colspan="1" rowspan="2"><div style="width: 
200px;"><strong>Organization and Summary of Significant Accounting 
Policies<br></strong></div></th>
<th class="th" colspan="1">6 Months Ended</th>
</tr>
<tr><th class="th"><div>Jun. 30, 2016</div></th></tr>
<tr class="re">
<td class="pl " style="border-bottom: 0px;" valign="top"><a class="a" 
href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.showAR( this, 'defref_us-
gaap_OrganizationConsolidationAndPresentationOfFinancialStatementsAbstract', 
window );"><strong>Organization, Consolidation and Presentation of Financial 
Statements [Abstract]</strong></a></td>
<td class="text">&#160;<span></span>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="ro">
<td class="pl " style="border-bottom: 0px;" valign="top"><a class="a" 
href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.showAR( this, 'defref_us-
gaap_OrganizationConsolidationBasisOfPresentationBusinessDescriptionAndAccountin
gPoliciesTextBlock', window );">Organization and Summary of Significant 
Accounting Policies</a></td>
<td class="text"><div style="text-align: justify"><table 
id="zf12e9e435642401ba06fa53bb5aa0f26" class="DSPFListTable" cellspacing="0" 
cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">
<tr>
<td style="width: 36pt; font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif; vertical-
align: top">1.</td>
<td style="text-align: justify; width: auto; font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, serif; vertical-align: top">Organization and Summary of Significant 
Accounting Policies</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Organization</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
Ridgewood Energy O Fund, LLC (the "Fund"), a Delaware limited liability company,
was formed on December 21, 2004 and operates pursuant to a limited liability 
company agreement (the "LLC Agreement") dated as of February 16, 2005 by and 
among Ridgewood Energy Corporation (the "Manager") and the shareholders of the 
Fund, which addresses matters such as the authority and voting rights of the 
Manager and shareholders, capitalization, transferability of membership 
interests, participation in costs and revenues, distribution of assets and 
dissolution and winding up.&#160; The Fund was organized to primarily acquire 
interests in oil and gas properties located in the United States offshore waters
of Texas, Louisiana and Alabama in the Gulf of Mexico.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
Manager has direct and exclusive control over the management of the Fund&#8217;s
operations.&#160; With respect to project investments, the Manager locates 
potential projects, conducts due diligence, and negotiates and completes the 
transactions.&#160; The Manager performs, or arranges for the performance of, 
the management, advisory and administrative services required for Fund 
operations.&#160; Such services include, without limitation, the administration 
of shareholder accounts, shareholder relations and the preparation, review and 
dissemination of tax and other financial information.&#160; In addition, the 
Manager provides office space, equipment and facilities and other services 
necessary for Fund operations.&#160; The Manager also engages and manages the 
contractual relations with unaffiliated custodians, depositories, accountants, 
attorneys, broker-dealers, corporate fiduciaries, insurers, banks and others as 
required. See Notes 2, 3 and 4.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Basis of Presentation</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">These
unaudited interim condensed financial statements have been prepared by the 
Fund&#8217;s management in accordance with accounting principles generally 
accepted in the United States of America (&#8220;GAAP&#8221;) and in the opinion
of management, contain all adjustments (consisting of only normal recurring 
adjustments) necessary to present fairly the Fund&#8217;s financial position, 
results of operations and cash flows for the periods presented.&#160; Certain 
information and note disclosures normally included in annual financial 
statements prepared in accordance with GAAP have been omitted in these unaudited
interim condensed financial statements.&#160; The results of operations, 
financial position, and cash flows for the periods presented herein are not 
necessarily indicative of future financial results.&#160; These unaudited 
interim condensed financial statements should be read in conjunction with the 
Fund&#8217;s December 31, 2015 financial statements and notes thereto included 
in the Fund&#8217;s Annual Report on Form 10-K filed with the Securities and 
Exchange Commission (&#8220;SEC&#8221;).&#160; The year-end condensed balance 
sheet data was derived from audited financial statements for the year ended 
December 31, 2015, but does not include all disclosures required by GAAP.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: left; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Use of Estimates</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires management 
to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and
liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities as of the date 
of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expense 
during the reporting period. On an ongoing basis, the Manager reviews its 
estimates, including those related to the fair value of financial instruments, 
net property balances, determination of proved reserves, impairment of long-
lived assets and asset retirement obligations. Actual results may differ from 
those estimates.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Fair Value Measurements</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
fair value measurement guidance provides a hierarchy that prioritizes and 
defines the types of inputs used to measure fair value. The fair value hierarchy
gives the highest priority to Level 1 inputs, which consists of unadjusted 
quoted prices for identical instruments in active markets. Level 2 inputs 
consist of quoted prices for similar instruments.&#160; Level 3 inputs are 
unobservable inputs and include situations where there is little, if any, market
activity for the instrument; hence, these inputs have the lowest priority.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Cash and Cash Equivalents</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">All 
highly liquid investments with maturities, when purchased, of three months or 
less, are considered cash equivalents. These balances, as well as cash on hand, 
are included in &#8220;Cash and cash equivalents&#8221; on the balance sheet. As
of June 30, 2016, the Fund had no cash equivalents. At times, deposits may be in
excess of federally insured limits, which are $250 thousand per insured 
financial institution.&#160; As of June 30, 2016, the Fund&#8217;s bank balances
were maintained in uninsured bank accounts at Wells Fargo Bank, N.A.</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">&#160;</div>
<div style="text-align: left; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Salvage Fund</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
Fund deposits in a separate interest-bearing account, or salvage fund, money to 
provide for the dismantling and removal of production platforms and facilities 
and plugging and abandoning its wells at the end of their useful lives in 
accordance with applicable federal and state laws and regulations. Interest 
earned on the account will become part of the salvage fund. There are no 
restrictions on withdrawals from the salvage fund.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times,
serif">Debt Discounts and Deferred Financing Costs</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">Debt 
discounts and deferred financing costs include lender fees and other costs of 
acquiring debt (see Note 3. &#8220;Credit Agreement &#8211; Beta Project 
Financing&#8221;) such as the conveyance of override royalty interests related 
to the Beta Project.&#160; These costs are deferred and amortized over the term 
of the debt period or until the redemption of the debt. During the first quarter
of 2016, the Fund adopted the accounting guidance issued in April 2015 related 
to the presentation of debt issuance costs on the balance sheet as a direct 
reduction from the carrying amount of the debt liability, rather than as an 
asset. As a result, the unamortized debt discounts and deferred financing costs 
of $0.5 million as of June 30, 2016 and $0.7 million as of December 31, 2015 are
presented as&#160;a reduction of &#8220;Long-term borrowings&#8221; on the 
balance sheets. Amortization expense was $0.1 million during each of the three 
months ended June 30, 2016 and 2015.&#160; Amortization expense was $0.2 million
during each of the six months ended June 30, 2016 and 2015.&#160; During the 
period of asset construction, amortization expense, as a component of interest, 
is capitalized and included on the balance sheet within &#8220;Oil and gas 
properties&#8221;.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: left; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Investment in Delta House</div>
<div>&#160;</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
Fund has investments in Delta House Oil and Gas Lateral, LLC and Delta House 
FPS, LLC (collectively &#8220;Delta House&#8221;), legal entities that own 
interests in a deepwater floating production system operated by LLOG Exploration
Company.&#160; The Fund accounts for its investment in Delta House using the 
cost method of accounting for investments as it does not have the ability to 
exercise significant influence over such investment.&#160; Under the cost 
method, the Fund recognizes an investment in the equity of an investee at 
cost.&#160;&#160; The Fund recognizes&#160;as income dividends received that are
distributed from net accumulated earnings of the investee since the date of 
acquisition by the Fund.&#160; Dividends received in excess of earnings 
subsequent to the date of investment are considered a return of investment and 
are recorded as reductions of cost of the investment. The Fund reviews its cost 
method investment for impairment at each reporting period and when an event or 
change in circumstances has occurred that may have significant adverse effect on
the fair value of the investment.&#160; As of June 30, 2016, there are no such 
events or changes in circumstances that indicate that the Fund&#8217;s 
investment in Delta House is impaired.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Oil and Gas Properties</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
Fund invests in oil and gas properties, which are operated by unaffiliated 
entities that are responsible for drilling, administering and producing 
activities pursuant to the terms of the applicable operating agreements with 
working interest owners. The Fund&#8217;s portion of exploration, drilling, 
operating and capital equipment expenditures is billed by operators.</div>
<div>&#160;</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,
serif">Exploration, development and acquisition costs are accounted for using 
the successful efforts method. Costs of acquiring unproved and proved oil and 
natural gas leasehold acreage, including lease bonuses, brokers&#8217; fees and 
other related costs are capitalized. Costs of drilling and equipping productive 
wells and related production facilities are capitalized.&#160; The costs of 
exploratory wells are capitalized pending determination of whether proved 
reserves have been found.&#160; If proved commercial reserves are not found, 
exploratory well costs are expensed as dry-hole costs.&#160; At times, the Fund 
receives adjustments to certain wells from their respective operators upon 
review and audit of the wells&#8217; costs.&#160; Interest costs related to the 
Credit Agreement (see Note 3. &#8220;Credit Agreement &#8211; Beta Project 
Financing&#8221;) are capitalized during the period of asset construction. 
Annual lease rentals and exploration expenses are expensed as incurred.&#160; 
All costs related to production activity, transportation expense and workover 
efforts are expensed as incurred.</div>
<div style="text-align: justify"><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">Once 
a well has been determined to be fully depleted or upon the sale, retirement or 
abandonment of a property, the cost and related accumulated depletion and 
amortization, if any, is eliminated from the property accounts, and the 
resultant gain or loss is recognized.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">As of
June 30, 2016 and December 31, 2015, amounts recorded in due to operators 
totaling $1.0 million and $0.5 million, respectively, related to capital 
expenditures for oil and gas properties.</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">&#160;</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Advances to Operators for Working Interests and Expenditures</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
Fund may be required to advance its share of the estimated succeeding 
month&#8217;s expenditures to the operator for its oil and gas properties. As 
the costs are incurred, the advances are reclassified to proved 
properties.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Asset Retirement Obligations</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">For 
oil and gas properties, there are obligations to perform removal and remediation
activities when the properties are retired. Upon the determination of a property
to be either proved or dry, a retirement obligation is incurred. The Fund 
recognizes the fair value of a liability for an asset retirement obligation in 
the period incurred.&#160; Plug and abandonment costs associated with 
unsuccessful projects are expensed as dry-hole costs.&#160; As indicated above, 
the Fund maintains a salvage fund to provide for the funding of asset retirement
obligations.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Syndication Costs</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Syndication costs are direct costs incurred by the Fund in connection 
with the offering of the Fund&#8217;s shares, including professional fees, 
selling expenses and administrative costs payable to the Manager, an affiliate 
of the Manager and unaffiliated broker-dealers, which are reflected on the 
Fund&#8217;s balance sheet as a reduction of shareholders&#8217; capital.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Revenue Recognition and Imbalances</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">Oil 
and gas revenues are recognized when oil and gas is sold to a purchaser at a 
fixed or determinable price, when delivery has occurred and title has 
transferred, and collectability of the revenue is reasonably assured.&#160; The 
Fund uses the sales method of accounting for gas production imbalances.&#160; 
The volumes of gas sold may differ from the volumes to which the Fund is 
entitled based on its interests in the properties.&#160; These differences 
create imbalances that are recognized as a liability only when the 
properties&#8217; estimated remaining reserves net to the Fund will not be 
sufficient to enable the underproduced owner to recoup its entitled share 
through production.&#160; The Fund&#8217;s recorded liability, if any, would be 
reflected in other liabilities.&#160; No receivables are recorded for those 
wells where the Fund has taken less than its share of production.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Impairment of Long-Lived Assets</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
Fund reviews the carrying value of its oil and gas properties annually and when 
management determines that events and circumstances indicate that the recorded 
carrying value of properties may not be recoverable.&#160; Impairments are 
determined by comparing estimated future net undiscounted cash flows to the 
carrying value at the time of the review.&#160; If the carrying value exceeds 
the estimated future net undiscounted cash flows, the carrying value of the 
asset is written down to fair value, which is determined using estimated future 
net discounted cash flows from the asset.&#160; The fair value determinations 
require considerable judgment and are sensitive to change.&#160; Different 
pricing assumptions, reserve estimates or discount rates could result in a 
different calculated impairment.&#160; Given the volatility of oil and natural 
gas prices, it is reasonably possible that the Fund&#8217;s estimate of 
discounted future net cash flows from proved oil and natural gas reserves could 
change in the near term.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Significant declines in oil and natural gas prices since fourth quarter 
2014 have impacted the fair value of the Fund&#8217;s oil and gas properties. 
During the six months ended June 30, 2016, the Fund recorded impairments of oil 
and gas properties of $13 thousand, which represented the carrying value of 
Eugene Island 346/347.&#160; The impairment was primarily attributable to 
declines in future oil and gas prices.&#160; There were no impairments of oil
and gas properties during the three months ended June 30, 2016 and during the 
three and six months ended June 30, 2015.&#160; If oil and natural gas prices 
continue to decline, even if only for a short period of time, it is possible 
that additional impairments of oil and gas properties will occur.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Depletion and Amortization</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Depletion and amortization of the cost of proved oil and gas properties 
are calculated using the units-of-production method.&#160; Proved developed 
reserves are used as the base for depleting capitalized costs associated with 
successful exploratory well costs, development costs and related facilities. The
sum of proved developed and proved undeveloped reserves is used as the base for 
depleting or amortizing leasehold acquisition costs.&#160; During the three and 
six months ended June 30, 2015, the Fund recorded $0.2 million of depletion 
expense related to adjustments to asset retirement obligations for fully 
depleted properties.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Income Taxes</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">No 
provision is made for income taxes in the financial statements.&#160; The Fund 
is a limited liability company, and as such, the Fund&#8217;s income or loss is 
passed through and included in the tax returns of the Fund&#8217;s 
shareholders.&#160; The Fund files U.S. Federal and State tax returns and the 
2013 through 2015 tax returns remain open for examination by tax 
authorities.</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">&#160;</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Income and Expense Allocation</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Profits and losses are allocated to shareholders and the Manager in 
accordance with the LLC Agreement.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Distributions</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Distributions to shareholders are allocated in proportion to the number 
of shares held.&#160; The Manager determines whether available cash from 
operations, as defined in the LLC Agreement, will be distributed. Such 
distributions are allocated 85% to the shareholders and 15% to the Manager, as 
required by the LLC Agreement.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Available cash from dispositions, as defined in the LLC Agreement, will 
be paid 99% to shareholders and 1% to the Manager until the shareholders have 
received total distributions equal to their capital contributions.&#160; After 
shareholders have received distributions equal to their capital contributions, 
85% of available cash from dispositions will be distributed to shareholders and 
15% to the Manager.</div>
<div style="text-align: justify"><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: italic bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Recent Accounting Pronouncements</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">In 
January 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#8220;FASB&#8221;) 
issued accounting guidance that requires, among other things, companies to 
measure investments in other entities, except those accounted for under the 
equity method, at fair value and recognize any changes in fair value in net 
income unless an election is made to record the investment at cost, less 
impairment and plus or minus subsequent adjustments for observable price changes
with change in basis reported in current earnings. This pronouncement is 
effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017 and interim periods
within those fiscal years, with early adoption not permitted. The Fund is 
currently evaluating the impact of this guidance on its financial 
statements.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">In 
April 2015, the FASB issued accounting guidance related to the presentation of 
debt issuance costs on the balance sheet as a direct reduction from the carrying
amount of the debt liability, consistent with debt discounts, rather than as an 
asset.&#160; Amortization of debt issuance costs will continue to be reported as
interest expense.&#160; In August 2015, the FASB issued accounting guidance 
related to the presentation and subsequent measurement of debt issuance costs 
associated with line-of-credit arrangements which clarifies that companies may 
continue to present unamortized debt issuance costs associated with line of 
credit arrangements as an asset.&#160; These pronouncements are effective for 
fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 
15, 2015, with early adoption permitted.&#160; The Fund adopted the accounting 
guidance in first quarter 2016, resulting in a one-time reclassification of $0.7
million of unamortized debt discounts and deferred financing costs from "Other 
assets" to "Long-term borrowings" on the balance sheet as of December 31, 2015. 
Long-term borrowings are presented net of $0.5 million of unamortized debt 
discounts and deferred financing costs as of June 30, 2016. The adoption of 
these pronouncements did not impact the Fund&#8217;s results of operations or 
cash flows.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">In 
2014, the FASB issued accounting guidance on revenue recognition, which provides
for a single five-step model to be applied to all revenue contracts with 
customers. In 2015, the FASB issued a deferral of the effective date of the 
guidance to 2018, with early adoption permitted in 2017. In May 2016, the FASB 
issued final amendments which provided narrow scope improvements and practical 
expedients related to the implementation of the guidance. The Fund is currently 
evaluating the impact of this guidance on its financial 
statements.</div><span></span>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<tr class="re">

Transactions [Abstract]</strong></a></td>
<td class="text">&#160;<span></span>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="ro">
<td class="pl " style="border-bottom: 0px;" valign="top"><a class="a" 
href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.showAR( this, 'defref_us-
gaap_RelatedPartyTransactionsDisclosureTextBlock', window );">Related
Parties</a></td>
<td class="text"><div style="text-align: justify"><table 
id="zb5f77307f8e14580baec6c3213916264" class="DSPFListTable" cellspacing="0" 
cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">
<tr>
<td style="width: 36pt; font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif; vertical-
align: top">2.</td>
<td style="text-align: justify; width: auto; font: bold 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, serif; vertical-align: top">Related Parties</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">Pursuant to the terms of the LLC Agreement, the Manager renders 
management, administrative and advisory services to the Fund.&#160; For such 
services, the Manager is entitled to an annual management fee, payable monthly, 
of 2.5% of total capital contributions, net of cumulative dry-hole and related 
well costs incurred by the Fund.&#160; Management fees during the three and six 
months ended June 30, 2016 were $0.3 million and $0.7 million, respectively. 
Management fees during the three and six months ended June 30, 2015 were $0.4 
million and $0.7 million, respectively.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
Manager is entitled to receive a 15% interest in cash distributions from 
operations made by the Fund.&#160; The Fund did not pay distributions during the
three and six months ended June 30, 2016 and during the three months ended June 
30, 2015. Distributions paid to the Manager during the six months ended June 30,
2015 were $27 thousand.</div>
<div>&#160;</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">At 
times, short-term payables and receivables, which do not bear interest, arise 
from transactions with affiliates in the ordinary course of business.</div>
<div><br />
</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">None 
of the amounts paid to the Manager have been derived as a result of arm&#8217;s 
length negotiations.</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
serif">&#160;</div>
<div style="text-align: justify; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, serif">The 
Fund has working interest ownership in certain projects to acquire and develop 
oil and natural gas projects with other entities that are likewise managed by 
the Manager.</div><span></span>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<div style="display: none;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData"

<a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+

<tr>
<td><strong> Name:</strong></td>
<td style="white-space:nowrap;">us-gaap_RelatedPartyTransactionsAbstract</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="padding-right: 4px;white-space:nowrap;"><strong> Namespace

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData"
